Chapter 5, Section 6: The Good and Evil Karmic Paths and the Attainment of Fruits, Part 6. What are the fruits obtained from the good and evil karmic paths?
Verse:
All can attract the fruits of retribution, equal flow, and predominance,
Because this causes others to suffer, cuts off life, and destroys dignity.
Discussion:
First, the ten evil karmic paths each attract three fruits.
What are the three?
Because of the distinctions in retribution, equal flow, and predominance.
It is said that if one practices, cultivates, or does much of the ten kinds, by the power of this one is born in the hells, which is the fruit of retribution.

Having left that realm, they are reborn in the human realm and experience the results that accord with the cause, namely, those who kill have a short lifespan, those who steal lack resources, those who engage in sexual misconduct have unfaithful spouses, those who speak falsely are often slandered, those who engage in divisive speech have discord with close friends, those who speak harshly always hear unpleasant sounds, and those who engage in idle chatter are not respected.

Those who are greedy have excessive greed, those who are hateful have increased hatred, and those who have wrong views have increased delusion. The dominant results that are similar to the cause are also called results that accord with the cause.
The dominant results produced by these ten are as follows: Due to killing, external resources have little luster;
due to stealing, they are often damaged by frost and hail, with meager harvests and few fruits;ğŸ”½due to sexual misconduct, they are full of dust and dirt;
due to false speech, they are full of foul odors;
due to divisive speech, the land is uneven;
Because of harsh speech, there are many evil contacts, such as fields full of thorns, barren, salty, and bitter.
Because of frivolous speech, the seasons change.
Because of greed, the fruits are few; because of anger, the fruits are spicy; because of wrong views, the fruits are few or none. These are called the dominant effects of the paths of action.
Does one killing karma lead to hell and also to a short life and external evil effects?
Other masters say:
The same killing karma first produces the ripening effect, then the proximate dominant effect, and finally the distant dominant effect. Therefore, there are three effects.

In reality, when killing, it causes the killed to suffer, lose their life, and destroy their majestic light. Because it causes others to suffer, one is born in hell. Because it ends another's life, one has a short life among humans.

First is the effect of the preparatory action, and later is the effect of the fundamental [karma]. The fundamental and its proximate stages are both called killing. Because it destroys majestic light and leads to evil external conditions, killing karma obtains three kinds of effects.
The other evil paths of action should be considered in the same way.
Therefore, you should understand the three fruits of the three good paths of action in the same way.
If you practice, cultivate, and do much of abstaining from killing, by the power of this you are born among the gods and receive the retribution fruit.

After death there, you are reborn among humans and receive the dominant fruit of a very long life. By this you also attract the dominant fruit of external things having great power and a distant dominant fruit.
The other three fruits of the good [paths of action] should be explained in the opposite way to the bad [paths of action].
Moreover, a scripture says:
Among the eight branches of wrong practice, wrong speech, wrong action, and wrong livelihood are distinguished as bodily and verbal actions.
Apart from wrong speech and wrong action, what is wrong livelihood?
Although it does not exist apart from them, it is separately explained. A verse says:
Bodily and verbal actions born from greed are wrong livelihood because they are difficult to eliminate.
Holding that livelihood is sustained by greed is unreasonable because it contradicts the scriptures.
The treatise says:
Bodily and verbal actions born from anger and delusion are respectively called only wrong speech and wrong action.

The two karmas of body and speech born of craving are called wrong speech and wrong action. They are also called wrong livelihood, because they are difficult to eliminate and are established separately from the other two.
Craving is subtle and can steal the minds of sentient beings. It is difficult to restrain even for a very wise person, so it is considered the most difficult to eliminate among the three.
For laypeople, wrong views are difficult to eliminate, because they are full of false attachments to auspiciousness, etc.
For monastics, wrong livelihood is difficult to eliminate, because all their conditions for livelihood depend on others.
In order to cultivate right livelihood with great care, the Buddha established it separately from the other two.
Other masters maintain that only the karmas of body and speech born of craving for the requisites of life are called wrong livelihood, not those born of other cravings.
Why is this?
Because one engages in singing, dancing, etc. for oneâ€™s own amusement, and this is not a means of livelihood.
This contradicts the scriptures, and therefore reason definitely does not support it.
The Sutra on the Collection of Moralities says that watching elephant fights, etc., are also included in wrong livelihood, because one falsely extends oneâ€™s life by observing external objects.
Therefore wrong livelihood is not only the body and speech produced by craving for the requisites of life.
Right speech, action, and livelihood are the opposite of these.

Among the paths of action, body is mentioned first and speech second, according to whether they are gross or subtle. In the case of the eight members of the path, speech is mentioned first and body second, according to whether they are produced in sequence. Therefore a scripture says, â€œAfter initial inquiry and investigation, one produces speech.â€
As previously explained, there are five results.
What kind of action has how many results?
The verse says:
Action of the path of elimination and impure action are endowed with five results.
Pure action has four, namely, excluding the result as retribution.
The rest, good and bad, also have four, excluding the result as disconnection.
The rest, pure and indeterminate, have three, excluding the above excluded results.
The verse says:
The path is able to realize and eliminate, and is able to eliminate the passions. It is given the name of the path of elimination, which is the uninterrupted path.
This path is of two kinds, namely, contaminated and uncontaminated.
The contaminated path has five fruits of action:

The fruit of similar outcome is the subsequent similar and enhanced dharmas of the same stage.ğŸ”½The fruit of retribution is the desirable retribution attracted by the path of elimination of the same stage.
The fruit of freedom is the unconditioned liberation realized by the power of this path in eliminating the passions.
The fruit of the dominant is the possession of the path, the liberation that accompanies it, and the cultivation of elimination.

cessation is also the dominant fruit of the path, because the power of the path is able to realize it. In the path of cessation, pure action has only four fruits, excluding the ripened fruit.

That is, the remaining pure and indeterminate action has only three fruits, excluding the two fruits that are excluded above, namely, the ripened fruit and the fruit of disconnection.

We have generally distinguished the various actions that have fruits. Next, we will discuss the characteristics of the various actions that have fruits. In this discussion, we will first discuss the three actions of good, etc.

Good, etc., with regard to good, etc., have four, two, and three fruits at the beginning.

That is, the first, good karma, has four results that are good dharmas, excluding the retributive result.

The similar result is that all bad karma that is eliminated by the path of insight into the truths of suffering and accumulation, and bad karma that is eliminated by the path of insight into the truth of accumulation, has as its similar result the indeterminate dharmas in the class of views of the body and of the extreme in the realm of desire.

Having distinguished the three time periods, we will now distinguish the various stages.
Verse:
The same stage has four fruits, different stages have two or three.
Treatise:
In the various stages, according to which stage the karma belongs, it takes the dharmas of the same stage as its four fruits, excluding disjunction.
If it is contaminated, it takes the dharmas of different stages as its two fruits, namely the human effort and dominant fruits.

If it is uncontaminated, it takes the dharmas of different stages as its three fruits, excluding the karmic maturation and disjunction fruits, because it does not fall into the realms, it does not block the homogeneous cause.
Having distinguished the various stages, we will now distinguish the learners, etc.
Verse:
Learners have three each in the three, non-learners have one, three, two,
Non-learners and neither-learners-nor-non-learners have two, two, five fruits.
Treatise:

Each of the three types of karma such as training, taking one by one as the cause, has three dharmas as its effect. The distinctions are as follows: The karma of training has the dharmas of training as its three effects, excluding the homogeneous and the disjunction effects.
Taking the dharmas of post-training as its three effects is also the same.
Taking the dharmas of neither training nor post-training as its three effects, excluding the homogeneous and the karmic maturation effects.
The karma of post-training has the dharmas of training as its one effect, which is the dominant effect.

Taking the dharmas of post-training as its three effects, excluding the karmic maturation and the disjunction effects.ğŸ”½Taking the dharmas of neither training nor post-training as its two effects, which are the human effort and the dominant effects.
The karma of neither training nor post-training has the dharmas of training as its two effects, which are the human effort and the dominant effects.
Taking the dharmas of post-training as its two effects is also the same.
Taking the dharmas of neither training nor post-training as its five effects.
Having explained the three types such as training, we will now explain the three types such as that which is eliminated by seeing.
The verse states:
The karma eliminated by seeing, etc., each has three [effects].
The first has three, four, and one [effects], the middle has two, four, and three effects,
The last one, the second, and the fourth, should all be understood in sequence.
The treatise says:
The three types of karma such as that which is to be eliminated by seeing, etc., each take three dharmas as their effects in sequence.
The specific explanation is: First, karma to be eliminated by seeing takes the dharmas to be eliminated by seeing as its three effects, excluding the karmic ripening and the disconnection effects.
It takes the dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation as its four effects, excluding the disconnection effect.
It takes the undefiled dharmas as its one effect, which is the dominant effect.
In the middle, karma to be eliminated by cultivation takes the dharmas to be eliminated by seeing as its two effects, which are the human effort and dominant effects.
It takes the dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation as its four effects, excluding the disconnection effect.
It takes the undefiled dharmas as its three effects, excluding the karmic ripening and the similar effect.
In the end, undefiled karma takes the dharmas to be eliminated by seeing as its one effect, which is the dominant effect.
It takes the dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation as its two effects, which are the human effort and dominant effects.
It takes the undefiled dharmas as its four effects, excluding the karmic ripening.
All of these are in order, and according to what is appropriate, they are all over the above various topics. The brief Dharma should be like this.
Having discussed the various karmas, we should ask again:

As for the three karmas explained in the original treatise, namely, karma that should be done, karma that should not be done, and karma that is neither to be done nor not to be done, what are their characteristics?
Verse:
Defiled karma should not be done. Some say it also destroys propriety.
Karma that should be done is the opposite of this. The third is contrary to both.
Treatise:
Some say that defiled bodily, verbal, and mental karma is called karma that should not be done, because it arises from improper attention.
Other masters say:
Bodily, verbal, and mental karma that destroys propriety, even if it is not defiled, should also not be done, because it does not accord with worldly propriety.

This refers to the bodily karma of the unrestrained and indeterminate, whether standing, walking, eating, drinking, etc. Those that do not accord with worldly etiquette are all called bodily karma that destroys propriety.
All non-defiled and non-defined verbal actions that violate propriety and decorum, as well as the agent, etc., are all called violations of propriety and decorum.
The two kinds of volition that initiate these are called violations of propriety and decorum of the mind. These and defiled actions are called improper.
Proper actions are the opposite of these.
Both violate the first two kinds of actions and are the third kind of action.
If one relies on worldly convention, the latter may also be so. If one adheres to the ultimate truth, the former is said to be good.
That is, only good actions are called proper, only defiled actions are called improper, and non-defiled and non-defined bodily, verbal, and mental actions are called neither proper nor improper.
However, not all improper actions are included in evil conduct. Only the unwholesome ones are called evil conduct because they are by nature evil.
That which brings about a desirable result is called good conduct, and that which brings about an undesirable result is called evil conduct.

Although the indeterminate with obstruction is not to be done, it is not included in evil conduct, because the activity of this mind is definitely unable to attract either a pleasant or unpleasant fruit.
Now we must consider this matter further: Is it that a single action only attracts a single birth, or does it attract many births?
Also, is it that a single birth is only attracted by a single action, or is it attracted by many actions?
A verse says:
One action attracts one birth, and many actions can perfect it.
The treatise says:
If one relies on correct principles, one should definitely say that only a single action attracts only a single birth.
The term one birth here refers to a homogeneous group, because only after obtaining a homogeneous group can one be said to have a birth.
If it is said that a single birth is attracted by many actions, or that a single action can attract many births, what error is there in these two statements?

First, there is an error, because in a single birth, if the fruit of a previous action ends and the fruit of a later action arises, since the fruits of action are different, there would either be death and rebirth or there would be multiple births.
If there is no death, then the results of karma will never occur, just as they do not in the first of the two mindless meditative attainments. Both of these views are faulty.

If you maintain that the intermediate existence is originally existent, then there must be many deaths and births in it. Or else, there would be no death or birth in it until the attainment of nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder.
Why is it that in a certain realm and mode of birth, the results of different karmas occur and there is birth and death,

but in other realms and modes of birth, the results of different karmas occur and there is no birth and death? It is reasonable to maintain that there is death and birth when the results of one karma are exhausted and the results of other karmas occur.

If you maintain that one life is definitely composed of many births, because it is attracted by many karmas that are created and increased, then it is certain that there is no premature death. Or else, you must admit that one does not experience the results of karma and that one abandons that karma forever.
We have already explained this.
What did we explain?ğŸ”½We explained that it is impossible for the results of karma that is fixed as to time to be experienced at a time different from that to which it is fixed.
We also explained that it is impossible for karma that is fixed as to time to be created and increased without the experience of results.

If you say that some beings die prematurely and some live out their natural terms because they are led by definite and indefinite karma, or because some are led by definite karma and others by indefinite karma, this is not so.

If you say that some beings die prematurely because they are led by definite and indefinite karma, or that some beings live out their full life spans because they are led by definite karma, this is also unreasonable. Because there is no certainty as to whether the results of karma are experienced at a specific time or not.

If there is a person who is in middle age, old age, or a stage of life in which the results of karma are definitely to be experienced, and if there is another person who is an infant, a child, or a youth in a stage of life in which the results of karma are not to be experienced, how can you explain this?

It is impossible for the latter to exist without the former. Or else, it would follow that the results of karma in the former stage of life are definitely to be experienced, while the results of karma in the latter stage of life are not to be experienced.

But there is no definite principle here that would require the results of karma in the former stage of life to be definitely experienced, while the results of karma in the latter stage of life are not to be experienced. Therefore, there is no single life that is led by many karmas.
The latter case also has errors. If one karma leads to many lives, then the definite karma of a specific time would become confused.
This confusion does not exist, as has already been explained. Therefore, no single karma can lead to many lives.
If this is so, why did the Venerable Aniruddha say:

I remember that once, in a single act of giving food to a superior field of merit, as a result of this I was reborn seven times in the Heaven of the Thirty-three and seven times as a wheel-turning sage king in the human realm, and in my last life I was born in the great ÅšÄkya family, with abundant wealth and much happiness.

The VaibhÄá¹£ikas have already explained this statement: in a single act of giving food, he gave rise to many superior thoughts, and the ability to attract many different results of retribution was due to these many thoughts and vows.

The result of a single act of giving food should not be able to give rise to rebirth again, but in order to show that the different states of the results of retribution attracted by many thoughts and vows based on a single act of giving food are different, he said this. Or it is said in order to show the initial basis.

Due to a single karma, he was able to be greatly honored, have much wealth, and have wisdom from past lives in the middle of a single life. Riding on this, he further created blessings that gave rise to other lives. In this way, he gradually reached his final life, was born in a wealthy and noble family, and attained the ultimate fruit.

For example, there is a case where someone, having obtained one kÄrá¹£Äpaá¹‡a, diligently seeks to increase it and obtains a thousandfold profit, saying, I have now become greatly wealthy and noble because of that one kÄrá¹£Äpaá¹‡a I obtained in the past.
Therefore, a single karma only attracts a single birth.

Although it is said that a single birth is attracted by a single karma, it is allowed that it is completed by many karmas, just as a painter first sketches the form with a single color and then fills in the various colors.
In this case, is the single color used as an analogy for a single type of karma or for a single moment?

If it is used as an analogy for a single type, it contradicts the principle of this school, because the statement that a single birth is attracted by a single karma cannot be based on a single type, because a type must be many.
It is unreasonable for many to attract a single birth.
If it is said that the single color is used as an analogy for a single moment, and a single moment cannot sketch a form, then the analogy established is unable to prove anything.
Now, seeing that here the analogy is for a single type of karma, how can the attracting karma be established based on a type?
because the karma that projects one destiny is manifold.

This statement intends to show that within one type of karma, only one moment projects the general similarity of sentient beings, while many moments of karma of the same or different types can perfect it. Therefore it is said to be manifold.
Therefore, even though one receives a human body, some are endowed with complete limbs, body, faculties, form, size, color, strength, and adornment,
while others may have many deficiencies. Is birth only projected and perfected by karma?
No, all karmas that are dharmas with one result, because their power is strong, also project and perfect birth. Those that are contrary to this can perfect but not project.
What are the natures of these two types?
Verse:
The two mindless samÄdhis obtain, but cannot project the other.
Treatise:
The two mindless samÄdhis, even though they have retribution, do not have the power to attract a class commonality, because they do not exist simultaneously with karma.
Obtained good and bad impure dharmas also do not have the power to attract a class commonality, because they are not the same fruit as karma.
The remaining good and bad impure dharmas are both able to attract and complete.
A scripture teaches,
There are three grave obstacles, namely, the obstacle of karma, the obstacle of the passions, and the obstacle of retribution.
What are the natures of these three obstacles?

The Treatise says that the substance of the obstacle of karma is the five heinous crimes: killing oneâ€™s mother, killing oneâ€™s father, killing an arhat, maliciously drawing blood from a buddha, and destroying the harmony of the Saá¹…gha.
As for the substance of the obstacle of the passions, it is the frequently occurring passions.

If the inferior passions occur frequently, even though one wishes to subdue and eliminate them, it is difficult to get the chance to do so, because they gradually cause the superior passions to arise, which are difficult to subdue and eliminate, and therefore they are also called obstacles.

If the superior passions do not occur frequently, the path of the antidote arises easily and one gets the chance to do so. Even though they are extremely violent, they are not included in the obstacles.
Even though a person in the realm of desire who is bound by all the bonds equally produces all the passions, there are differences in their actual activity, and the obstacles are not the same.
Therefore, among the passions, those that are frequently occurring, whether inferior or superior, are called the obstacle of the passions.

As for the substance of the obstacle of retribution, it is the three evil destinies in their entirety and a part of the good destinies, namely, the northern continent Uttarakuru and the mindless heaven.
Why are they called obstacles?
Because they obstruct the holy paths, the equipment for the paths, and the separation from passions.
Even though there are other actions that can obstruct the path of insight, they can be turned away from, unlike the five heinous crimes.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say:
These five causes are easy to see and easy to know, and are said to be karmic hindrances, namely, place, realm, birth, fruit, and individual.
The establishment of the other hindrances should be considered in the same way.
Among these three hindrances, afflictions are the most serious, because they can give rise to karma, and karma leads to the fruition.
Other masters say:
The two hindrances of afflictions and karma are both the most serious, because those who have them cannot be cured even in the second life.
What is the meaning of uninterrupted?
This uninterrupted karma is necessarily experienced in the next life without interruption, because no other karma can obstruct the fruition in the next life.
Some say:
The individual who commits the heinous crimes will definitely fall into hell after death, because there is no interruption, and it is called uninterrupted.
Which realms among the three realms have these three hindrances?
In verse it is said:
Uninterrupted [karma] exists in the three continents, not in others, such as Uttarakuru, etc.
Little kindness and little shame, the other hindrances are common to the five destinies.
The treatise says:
Not all obstacles exist in all destinies. First, the uninterrupted karma exists only in the three continents of humans, not in Uttarakuru, nor in other destinies or realms.
Within the three continents, it exists only for women and men, not for eunuchs, etc., like the absence of evil precepts.
Some say:
Because parents have little kindness towards them, and they have little shame towards their parents.
This means that their parents give birth to an incomplete body, and their love and care are minimal, so it is said their kindness is little.
They also have little shame and conscience towards their parents. Only when one has a heavy sense of shame and conscience does one commit the crime of immediate retribution.
If someone harms the parents of non-humans, they also do not commit the crime of immediate retribution, because of their little kindness and shame.
This means that they have no kindness towards their child like humans do, and the child has no shame and conscience towards them like humans do.
It has been explained that the obstacle of karma exists only in the three continents of humans. The other obstacles should be known to exist in all five destinies.
However, the obstacle of afflictions is found everywhere.
If there is an obstacle to retribution, it is completely in the three evil destinies, humans are only in the northern continent, and gods are only in the non-percipient heaven.
Among the three kinds of obstacles explained above, the five heinous acts are said to be the substance of the obstacle of karma.
What is the substance of the five heinous acts?
Verse:
Among these five heinous acts, four are bodily actions and one is verbal action,
three are killing, one is false speech, and one is the preparatory action of killing.
Commentary:
Among the five heinous acts, four are bodily actions and one is verbal action. Three are killing and one is false speech.
One is the preparatory action of the path of killing, because the body of the TathÄgata cannot be harmed.
The heinous act of schism is false speech.
Since it is false speech, why is it called schism?
It is named after the result, or because it can cause schism.
If so, what is the substance of schism?
Who accomplishes the schismatic and the schismed?
Verse:
The schism of the Saá¹…gha is a non-coalescence, a non-concordance, a non-coordination, an unassociated formative force,

In this way, the schism of the Saá¹…gha arises from false speech. Therefore, it is said that the result of the schism of the Saá¹…gha is without obstruction.

In verse, it says:
The one who splits the Saá¹…gha only accomplishes the offense of false speech,

However, one who commits this offense does not pass through a great kalpa, because there is no such life span in the realm of desire, and the time of one intermediate kalpa is not yet complete.
